Late time behavior of closed isotropic models in
second order gravity theory
John Miritzis,
Department of Marine Sciences, University of the Aegean,
University Hill, Mytilene 81100, Greece
Abstract
Homogeneous and isotropic closed models are studied in both the Einstein
and the Jordan frame of the second order gravity theory. The normal form of
the dynamical system has periodic solutions for a large set of initial conditions.
This implies that an initially expanding closed isotropic universe may exhibit
oscillatory behavior.

In this paper we investigate the late time evolution of positively curved FRW
models with a perfect fluid in the R + βR2 theory. The simple vacuum case was
studied in [1], where oscillatory behavior of the solutions of closed models was found.
Since there is no universally acceptable answer to the issue "which conformal frame
is physical", (see for example [2]), it should be interesting to compare the solution
in the Jordan frame with the solution of the same problem obtained in the Einstein
frame. In the following, we confine our attention to cosmologies with a perfect fluid
with energy density ρ and pressure p, of the form p = (γ − 1)ρ, 0 ≤ γ ≤ 2.
We begin our study in the Einstein frame. The scalar field is minimally coupled
to ordinary matter. The Einstein equations reduce to the constraint

Obviously we cannot assign a physical meaning to the new variables (r, θ, x, y),
since the transformations involved in the normal form have "mixed" the original
variables in a nontrivial way. However, the periodic character of the solutions whatever the physical meaning of the variables be, has the following interpretation. Close
to the equilibrium of the original system, there exist periodic solutions.
This feature is not revealed in the Einstein frame, possibly because, the scalar
field related to the conformal transformation is not coupled to matter, i.e., the
matter Lagrangian is added after performing the conformal transformation.
In a recent work [5], we consider a scalar field having an arbitrary, bounded
from below potential function V (φ) , nonminimally coupled to matter. For flat and
negatively curved FRW models, our preliminary results indicate that the energy
exchange between the two matter components is such that:
If γ < 1 the energy density ρ eventually dominates over the energy density of
the scalar field ǫ and this universe follows the classical Friedmannian evolution. For
γ > 1, ǫ eventually dominates over ρ.
